job_title: Anonymous Employee in Panama City, FL
pros: Great coworkers, OK benefits, onsite dining facility, health club discount. You can easily apply to move between certain jobs and departments to learn new skills, if you qualify.
cons: Demoralized work environment, frequent unfair dismissals of stellar staff members, understaffed in crucial medical personnel. You can go to your job of several years in the morning, be called to a meeting at noon and go home unemployed. Also, it was hard seeing dedicated nurses and CNAs crying because they were so exhausted by long hours, frustrated and feeling so guilty because there's not enough help to properly care for their patients. People are suffering there, both patients and healthcare workers. LHP and CEO Barry Keel appear not to care about anything but the financial bottom line. It's truly a waste of a talented and compassionate staff and a fine state-of-the-art medical facility. Worse, it's a grave disservice to the people of Bay County who put their trust and their lives in the hands of these uncaring bureaucrats.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Panama City, FL
pros: There is all the work available that you can handle.  Hospital setting will give you opportunities to build your skills in any area which you chose.  You generally work 3 shifts 12-13 hours long.   The managers will work with you to try to accommodate needs for school/family.  If the floor you work on isn't your thing you can apply for other positions within the hospital.
cons: Pay is pretty low for RNs.  Once you are skilled there are many other outside agencies that offer much better pay.  A lot of the equipment is outdated, in low supply or just not available.  It can make a fast paced already stressful job very frustrating when time is wasted searching for equipment and supplies.  High turnover rate.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Panama City, FL
pros: Competition for Gulf Coast (HCA) and a needed resource for the county.  Great people in the ranks.
cons: Sold To LHP and did not live up to promises.  Lack real honesty and ethics from the Top, down.  Vendors are greedy and don't show good faith in their reporting.  A fake reason to sell out the tenured employees to a vendor!  Promotions are for those who narc on others, and bow down to Administration and the inept leadership.  A real lack of trust and honesty from Administration -- it shows in the employee surveys and in the bottom line.  Watch out:  Gulf Coast will eat your market share and take your patients -- due to your treatment of employees and the way you manage!

review_title: People Not Very Interested In Helping Others (Co-Workers)
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Panama City, FL
pros: Few. Pay is now comparable to other locations in Florida. Some individuals are helpful but others there do not like the ones that are helpful being so...
cons: Working at BMC was very different than almost all of the other handful of hospitals I have had a chance to work with. People are super-critical, only have time for themselves and are not welcoming to new employees all-around. I think it stemmed from the take-over of the new management/owners and the feeling that they could be replaced by others.

job_title: Charge Nurse II in Panama City, FL
pros: If you enjoy patient care (or patient catering), well they do that
cons: Everything is bad. They only care about the bottom line. This place never has any staff,  never does anything to retain staff, benefits are subpar,  you will never get a raise even with spotless performance reviews because they're going broke paying top dollar to get docs to practice there (which those docs will not only accept payment from the hospital but also bill patients and then claim that they're not employees). I worked here for 10 years including very few weeks without overtime, came in on my day off,  stayed late to help, had great performance reviews and only got 2 raises in 10 years! I love being a nurse but I've got to make a living.

review_title: Disappointing, frustrating, looking for new job as most employees are
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Panama City, FL
pros: If you're in the right department with the right group of people, you may actually enjoy working here.  If your manager is educated, knowledgeable, and a real leader, it can be a good experience.
cons: Most departments are managed by people who don't know what they're doing.  They don't know how to handle personnel.  They certainly don't know how to lead, which is an order of magnitude more difficult than simply managing.  The higher level "leadership" is out of touch with what is really happening at the hospital and manage from behind a desk, in meetings, and looking at pieces of paper instead of getting out into the field.  Pay is horrendous.  Almost every employee I talked to over the years is looking for a new job.  Management doesn't know how to fix problems or even identify them.  But, they all know how to have useless meetings.

review_title: Up and down never consistent, Stagnation,
job_title: Patient Care Tech in Panama City, FL
pros: Decent insurance benefits, Meal discount, Paid time off for full time employees. Gym discounts across town.
cons: Currently very poor staffing conditions. I am unable to properly care for patients when I am over so many. When I am unable to take the time with them that I would like to I feel as if I am failing them and this makes work difficult. The people on my shift/days are an outstanding team we work very well together but do not have the staff to go around. This is very dangerous for our patients/customers. people who need to be feed don't, those who are soiled stay soiled longer, those that become acutely ill don't get help in the time they should. etc.. etc.. No raises with out additional education ie college degrees. at least that is what I have been told. Random promised bonuses for coming in when not scheduled that you later have to fight for to get.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Panama City, FL
pros: I absolutely loved my coworkers. Even when I had to float to other floors, even though it wasn't "home," I never had an issue with coworkers.
cons:
Depending on the unit you work on, you may not have adequate supplies, working equipment, or adequate staffing. Patient care suffers due to the poor staffing. I feel not all employees, especially new graduates, are trained as well as they could be. They did start an RN residency program but when I first started working there it was not required.
Since hurricane Michael, there was a lot of back and forth over whether or not employees would be paid during reconstruction of the hospital. Official word was put out that we would (full time and part time employees anyway). Then we had to sign a contract saying we wanted hurricane compensation (i.e. to continue to be paid) but we wouldn't seek other employment and would stay with the hospital for 6 months. I was unable to sign this due to having to relocate due to the hurricane, so I had to resign. Ascension then bought the hospital. Then they laid off 800+ employees via text/email (all getting the same letter) then posted new job openings on their website. Very poor communication throughout it all. So many were away from their families during the hurricane and negating their own needs outside of the hospital to help with patients can keep the hospital running only for the hospital to turn around and say, "thank you for being there for us but we're laying you and most everyone else off. And we're going to remove the "careers" link from our website so, unless you search for it, you can't see we're posting new job openings."

job_title: CSA in Panama City, FL
pros: Get to work with a lot of great people.
cons: Tons of constant change to policy and procedures. Also no raises have been given for years and there is constant turn around of employees and often have to work short handed due to not enough staff.

review_title: Great place to start work and continue to work, but start where you want to work because it has been difficult to xfer.

job_title: PRN RN (No Benefits) in Panama City, FL
pros:
It's in PC (if that matters to you)
Part-time is two shifts a week and you get all the benefits except pto
cons:
Ratio on the floors is frequently 6 or 7 to one.
Even a PRN nurse has to work one shift a week.
Scheduling is unpredictable and random.
Mandatory uniforms
Small rooms. Poor building design. No lifts.
Staffing by acuity is a new concept at this facility, let that sink in. They introduced the idea summer of 2016.
